Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Expectation2: Participate in project planning and provide accurate time estimates
Situation2: The planning session is informal, and the timeline can still shift without major impact
Story: I was sipping my coffee when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, someone I knew from a few gatherings, asking if I could help him move some boxes to his new apartment that afternoon. He sounded a bit desperate—apparently, his other helpers had bailed. As an acquaintance, I felt that familiar tug: I should help, at least to be decent. But just as I was about to reply, a Slack notification popped up. My project manager wanted to start an informal planning session in an hour. As the team’s engineer, I was expected to join, discuss the new features, and give my best guess at how long things would take. The session wasn’t set in stone, but my input would shape the next few weeks. I stared at my phone, feeling the pressure from both sides. Mark needed a hand, and I didn’t want to let him down. But my team was counting on me to be present and thoughtful. My stomach twisted as I weighed the expectations, caught between being a helpful acquaintance and a responsible engineer, knowing I couldn’t fully satisfy both.
